labels.title: 14.652, X1179.4
labels.content:
The ideal votive animal mummy, as shown in the X-ray here, contains one animal wrapped in the linen package. Yet without an X-ray or CT scan, it is impossible to know whether an additional animal, or no animal at all, was included in the wrappings.

Egyptians of the first millennium b.c.e. believed that they could appeal to the god Thoth to intercede in human affairs. Ibis mummies allowed such a petitioner to send a message to the god.

collections.name: Egyptian, Classical, Ancient Near Eastern Art

exhibitions.title: Soulful Creatures: Animal Mummies in Ancient Egypt

images.caption: Ibis Mummy, 30 B.C.E.– 100 C.E. Animal remains (female glossy ibis), linen, 4 3/4 × 3 5/8 × 12 3/4 × 14 1/2 in. (12.1 × 9.2 × 32.4 × 36.8 cm). Brooklyn Museum, Gift of the Egypt Exploration Fund, 14.652. Creative Commons-BY (Photo: Brooklyn Museum (Gavin Ashworth,er), 14.652_Gavin_Ashworth_photograph.jpg)
